segments.text: Okay.
At the conclusion of my narrative, with a phrase, quote, this officer possesses outstanding potential to the Army, end quote.
And I know that that had some impact on the general officer board
that each of those gentlemen went to because each one of them told me after it's all over said they quoted that to me and I didn't realize you thought that of me but I was telling the truth.
I was impressed with both their capabilities and so expressed it and it was part of their making general officer anyway.
They were outstanding and had outstanding capabilities and

If this country, I don't know whether it's both active still or not, but if this country ever goes to war where there'll be top flight general officers, I'd be happy to serve with either one of them, under either one of them.
I knew them as majors and lieutenant colonels, and there's where you cut the boys away from the men real quick.
and both of them were outstanding men in their jobs.
Okay.
Now, tell me why you switched or how it came about that you switched from the 90th Infantry Division to the commander, the CO, or the 401st Field Artillery.
No.
Because I moved out of town, and I'll have to find the dates on that.
I moved out of town, and...
Well, that was back in 54.
So you left the 90th.
I left the 90th, and all these remarks happened after I went back to the 90th.
I had a lapse there.
I moved out of town.
That meant I could no longer associate on these every Thursday night or every Sunday drills.
Where'd you go?
As I remember, I went to New Orleans working.
I know I did.
I went to New Orleans.
Got a job down there, and I couldn't participate with them, so the next thing to do was to put me in a holding group
and get me out of that active spot.
And I stayed there in the 90, I mean in the 4-1st group.
And I remember there was a paper shuffle somewhere that I got into to artillery corps, corps artillery.
401st group.
I was still in the 401st group.
It has some dates.
I can run this thing.
From 1940... Chronological speaking again now.
From 1947 to 19... June 47 to September 48, I was commander of the 4th First Field Artillery Group.
And then, in a shuffle of paper designations and all, from September of 48 to June of 50, I was commander of the 33rd Corps Artillery, which is again a paper outfit.
It was a headquarters, purely and simply.
enlisted people, no equipment or anything.
And then September 50 is when I joined the division artillery as the 9th division artillery as executive officer and then I stayed with them until 54.
Well, let me find some orders here.
That's what you said before.
Oh, I'm running backwards.
Okay.
Let me get like this.
53, I was in the group.
September of 53 I was in the group.
Which group?
401st group.
Oh, okay, so the 90th Infantry Division went from 1950 to 1953 then?
No.
In 54 I'm in the 401st group.
55 is when I went to the
to the 90th Division Artillery.
As commanded.
As commanded, that's correct.
And that's where I assumed command of it on 28th of April, 55.
And I commanded it until retired and retired.
And you made general on the 20th of January, 1956.
I'll tell you that.
I'll check that in just a minute.
I'm looking for an order here, as I'll have.
effective 20th January, 56 is when I made general.
Here's a telegram from chief of staff in Washington.

Promotion, announcement made of your promotion as a reserve commission officer in the army and greater brigadier general was assigned to the army reserve in the United States effective 20th January, 56.
And so that was, I was commander of the of the 90th division artillery at that time and uh
And you remained the commander until your retirement?
Until my retirement.
General Rutter was the division commander and he was the one, of course, that recommended me for the job.
I was promoted as such.
What were your feelings when you were promoted, Bill?
Very, very few colonels ever become generals.
Well, my feelings were
I was numb that I had been recommended and would be promoted to general and never dreamed of such a promotion or a recognition.
I was overwhelmed when I realized the responsibility of it.
I'd been a freelancing battalion commander, so to speak.
And all I had to do was look after my 400 and few people and do my job.
And that was fine.
I was happy and all.
But this thing completely took me out of the category of a small unit commander and gave me a very large unit.
And the responsibility, it took a month for it to soak in on me and me realize that it was true that I'd been promoted to a BG.
And it's something that's ultimate in professional Army.
And I just...
pinch myself, figure out if it's sure enough it's me.
But then again, I felt it was very easy to slide in and do the job because I've been doing it for so long.
It really didn't make any difference except your...
The more responsibility and the more
recognition you get.

I mean, I could call down to the Fourth Army as a colonel and fuss all day on the telephone without getting an answer, but if I was a brigadier general, I got put in right on, ahead of everything else, and I got an answer, period.
You're a different, you're a different status in the Army.
You're,
The very weight of what you say bears so much influence.
As a colonel, you go down to the officer's club and get tight if you wanted to and wheel on home, but you can't do that as a brigadier general or any general officer.
You've got to set the pattern, and you've got to demonstrate and live by it.
You can't tell people how to live and not live that way yourself.

And so it changes your perspective and I kept about my business and assured General Rutter that he'd be proud of his division artillery and that's when I set my goals of setting up this combat proficiency test to
as a goal for each of my battalions.
And they knew it.
I told them way ahead of time, before I ever announced it, to give them time to react to it.
And frankly, if they didn't want to do it, well, I'd get another commander.
Because that's what I had as my goal.
And I knew that, in all probability, I'd be retiring in 1962 at the end of my 30 years.
And that's what I wanted to do.
And I set about doing it.
We, that combat proficiency test is set out on the regulations and it's standard.
It's like passing one of your history courses in college.
You prepare for it, you work after it,
and you've got to train every soldier in his job and he has to be proficient or the thing will break down.

And like I say, the second year we did it, Colonel Kokonos and Colonel Butler's battalions passed it, the third year, and I think it was, it was, uh, uh, Carnegie's battalion out of San Antonio in the fourth year, it was, uh, Saget's battalion there in Austin passed it.
That's the way I remember it.
So of course, after one's passed it, it's easy for them to pass it.
And so there again, the Kokonos passed it three years, and Butler three years, and the third one two years, and one year, which qualified that division artillery to go in combat immediately.
And that's the ultimate of the reserve program is to prepare
The enlisted reserves are the reserves to take over the responsibilities of the active army and to join with the active army and as far as I was concerned, to be as good as active army or better.
Which brings us to another point.
In 1950, the United States went to war against North Korea.
and you were not called back in.
There were very few reservists that were called back in.
What were your feelings toward that?
That's their business.
If they needed a 9th Divardy, they'd call us and they didn't need us.
Did you want to go or did you have any pro or con feelings?
I had no brothers one way or the other about it.
I was prepared.
My battalion, my divarty was prepared.
And the decision on what units went and what units didn't go was made in Army headquarters.
Had they wanted to call the 9th Divarty and General Elder would have called me, I'd have said, yes, sir, we're ready.
Or I'd have said, we'll be ready in 30 days or 60 days or something.
But I could have said, we're ready.
The Army didn't dip into the reserves that deep.
They took some National Guard units, but they didn't take any reserve units as such.
Okay.
Now during the time that you were the commanding general, you must have had more blacks and women join the reserves, did you?
Or could you tell me, could you address those two topics, blacks and women in the reserve, and give me your feelings on that?
I think it...
My feelings are that getting back beyond the minority business, I think that we ought to have universal military service, period.
Truman's idea.
I don't know.
Certainly my idea, that we ought to have universal military training, and every youngster coming along should do two years, 18 months, one year, whatever,
the powers that be think would be an adequate time to train him or her.
Women included?
Women included.
I don't believe in women in a combat role, but there are supportive roles that they can do immensely well.
One time in combat, for instance, I had this infallibly driven home.
My wife wrote to me every day.
My mother wrote to me once or twice a week.
And one time I didn't get the letters for two months.
And I figured that something damn bold got sunk or something, you know, I didn't pay attention to it, except I was busy.
But I did miss my letters from my wife and my mother.
General Patton was down in some outfit, one of his Third Army outfits, talking with some of the soldiers, and the old man would do that
frequently.

He'd get in a mess line with them and just discuss problems, how they're getting along, they're getting, are the officers taking care of you, you get plenty of food, you're getting a can of beer down the end, you're getting a little mail.
No, sir, General, I haven't had any mail in three weeks or five or six weeks.
And it panned out most of his answers were he hadn't, they hadn't had any mail in six or eight weeks.
Well, General Patton was of the
the capabilities and the seniority that he went to Paris, where the Comzee communication zone headquarters is, was.
And he went in and asked about the mail, and of course they couldn't give him an answer.
The APO mail was all being flown out to Orly Field.
And he found that out somehow.
And he went out there, and my God, there were hangar after hangar stacked full to the ceiling of mail that hadn't been handled.
And he got to digging into it as a very senior three-star general.
And this shows the swife that one of those people could take.
He found out that there were two battalions of
black wax assigned to handling mail.
And instead of sorting and shipping the mail out to the units, they were playing around, crowding around all night and sleeping all day.
General Patton, when he found that out, he went and saw it himself.
He went to Comzee Commander and relieved him, two-star general.
Sent him home as lieutenant colonel.
He sent home two brigadier generals.
as lieutenant colonels and it absolutely devastated their careers.
He moved those people out of there and sent them home.
Got a bunch of his tankers that were on rest somewhere and up there and started to bail out and I remember I got 58 letters at one time.
Gee whiz.
These other generals just didn't know this was going on?
Didn't know it was going on and they didn't
get out of their office downtown or their officer's club or something to go see about it.
But General Patton- Have they heard any complaints?
Well, the complaints hadn't gotten to them, I guess.
Let's just say it that way.
Because the general officer should have, he should have picked it up first place.
In the second place, it shouldn't have ever happened.
But they just weren't doing their job.
And General Patton, when he picked it up out in his mess line somewhere, that soldier hadn't gotten any letters for six or eight weeks.
Well, he went to see why.
And because of his tenacity and because of his seniority, he had the rank to do it.
And he did it.
So that was a good place to put female soldiers, starting male out.
because there's no combat exposure there.
There's no rigid duty and it has to be done.
It took, General Pattinson sent some of his two, three battalions of his tankers back there.
Left his tanks under guards wherever they were, sent them back there and they did it in a couple weeks.
Broke the backlog down and got it operating.
But that was a good place to put female soldiers.
Now you get some screams about they're not doing

soldier work and all but took soldiers to do the job and they did relieve able-bodied men soldiers to do the fighting uh I don't know what percent I'm sure 20 or 25 percent of the army is is overhead army around headquarters particularly and I know you saw a
a male able-bodied male that could do combat being an air packing typewriter.
So female soldiers have a very definite place in the Army.
I wouldn't say combat because they're not equipped for combat.
They don't have the physical capabilities for combat, but they do have physical capabilities doing office work, which is necessary, the administrative work, and handling the mail, for instance.

Okay, in the late 1940s and throughout the war in Korea, President Truman integrated the army units and before this time of course we had black units, we had white units, and then he integrated this must have had some effect on the reserves.
Could you talk about that?
It had effect on reserves in that there was a transition period.
didn't bother me because my philosophy is red, yellow, black, or white, they're precious in his sight.
Jesus loves the little children of the world.
There was a Sunday school song that I learned 65 years ago.
Those words in it, and I can't ever remember violating it.
There was some resentment.
Surely there was some resentment.
But some of the white boys and the black soldiers coming in.
On the other hand, the black soldiers that came in to me, I warned and made my people treat them as equals.
And I say made in that I busted one sergeant because he didn't do it.
And that word gets around fast.
On the other hand... One sergeant in a reserve unit?
A white sergeant in a reserve unit.
On the other hand, those were signs of times.
The transition had to be made.
It was by executive order.
And those, as far as I was concerned, that was Army regulations, which means law, and that was it.
And we turned out some mighty good black
enlisted people, and I have served with some high-quality black officers.
There's no room for dissent on that subject, and those that fight that problem are just, they should know they're fighting a losing battle.
Yeah, okay.
That's not the American philosophy.
They could as well say they're against German heritage people or Polish heritage people or Italian heritage people or African heritage people.
They're all the same to me.
And if a man will present himself as a soldier, do his job, why?
Red, yellow, black, or white, I don't care.
Now were there any, except for this sergeant, when you were the commander,
Except for this one sergeant that you had to ever leave, were there any problems besides that?
Any little riots or anything?
No, no, no, no, no, no.
I never saw any real problems at all.
And his was passive.
His was passive.
I busted him because he wasn't doing his job of training that man, period.
And whether that man's black, white, red or yellow, I didn't care.
But he wasn't doing his job of training that man.
And I didn't bust him for...
not integrating with the man.
I bust him for not doing his job.
Okay.

Now, when you think back on your military career, going all the way up to general, did you leave, I like your opinion of this, did you leave your advancement to fate or to luck or something or to your superiors, or did you think that you yourself had some control over your promotions?
The only control I had
ever had, Terry, is doing my job.
A long time ago, and I told you this story initially of how an army just saying never hurry, never worry, never volunteer for nothing.
That is to some degree true.
The volunteer part is the true part.
The other is not true.
I told you the story of my friend that got out of Leavenworth the same time I did.
swapped my name for his on an order going to Portugal and he is lost because of that and I'm here today.
I never once asked for a job and I never once asked to get out of a job.
When I was given a job, I energetically and tried enthusiastically to do that job and
If you do that, your superiors can't help but recognize it, and time comes for them to make a recommendation for promotion.
They could recommend somebody that did that job.
So it seems to me like you left, and I don't want to put words in your mouth, but it seems to me that you left your advancement to your superiors.
Without a doubt.
Every move I made, I never asked to be transferred to any organization.
I certainly never asked to be promoted.
Well, most people who reach the pinnacle of the military or any organization, many would say that these people are ambitious.
Would you consider yourself ambitious?
Ambitious only to the sense that I was obsessed with doing my job in an excellent manner.
The Army terminology is superior.
You think of excellence as being the pinnacle in your teaching profession and college careers and all this kind of business.
Well, in the Army, you have five categories, superior, excellent, very satisfactory, satisfactory, and unsatisfactory.
So my goal, and I energetically pursued it,
of being superior, doing the best job possible.
And I've reiterated a half dozen instances where my work was recognized and I profited by it.
I could see this, that you do your job or you'll be recognized.
Okay, is that the same idea that you have toward being an engineer?
That's right.
What about this idea?
Here's another idea I'd like you to answer or address yourself to.
You're not only a success as far as the military, but you're a leader, a former owner of your own company.
Do you think that getting ahead in the military, how people get ahead, how people get promoted in the military, is similar or different than how they do that in the business world?
I think it's very similar in that if you do your job, your superiors are going to recognize you.
And if they gave you more responsibility, you're carrying more load, it means they will promote you up to a higher echelon of supervision.
Well, that means more pay.
And after every one, I was looking for more pay.
I carried that philosophy every day in my business.
And I commended and rewarded the job superintendents that were making money.
And that means running a good job, doing their job.
They're doing their job better than the rest of them.
And that's reading.
Two of them made top wages, and one of them made mediocre wage, I mean average wage, and two of them made subpar wages.
Purely and simply, recognition of their capabilities.
I treated them all alike, but when it comes to the paychecks, it was a different story.
Because one of them was making more money for me, meaning I could pay him more money.
And that man, he was excelling.
He was doing a superior job.
and the others were doing average jobs.
Let's talk for a few minutes about leadership.
We've touched on this throughout these interviews, but we have never defined it so far.
Would you give me your definition of leadership?
Leadership.
I think that's the demonstrated quality of getting the job done by virtue of other people doing it for you.
you've got to give them the leadership to get them to accomplish their job.
It's nothing more than the bag of carrots out in front of the mule.
And if you can keep that mule pulling, why, you're gonna get your job done.
To me, leadership is having the
confidence in yourself that you can do that job.

If you're equipped with the technical knowledge and you can demonstrate the practical application of your technical knowledge with your confidence and exuberance over it, you can portray it ultimately to the fellas doing the work.
And you've got to work through chains of command.
You can't be riding herd over every man.
In the Ninth Divardy, I changed commanders a lot.
Purely and simply, weeding out the mediocre, the average, or the excellent ones to get superior ones.
And I think my judgment was borne out by General Kokonos and General Butler as two of the four.
I think it... Well, what type of values should a leader have?
You mentioned values.
You mentioned one.
You said self-confidence.
What other values should a leader have?
Well, he's got to be technically capable.
Sure.
He's got to know what he's doing.
Absolutely.
And he's got to be right.
And above all, he's got to be honest.
He's got to be honest and not try to hoodwink anybody
and he's got to be the first man to say, I got, I was wrong on that one.
Let's don't let that happen again.
It doesn't uh- So he can admit mistakes.
Huh?
So he can admit mistakes.
You bet.
He's got to admit a mistake.
Uh, the, the uh, proof of the pudding is don't make them, but if you ever make one, be the first to admit it before anybody else finds it out.
And uh, all you can do is just say,
I gotta stump my toe on that and let's don't do that no more.
Then is the leader flexible?
I think he is.
He makes up his mind to do a certain thing at a certain time by all the information he has at that time.
And that's the correct decision to make.
And come back a week later and the changes of information can change his decision.
He has to be flexible.

If something doesn't work, you gotta approach it from another angle to get around to wherever you want to go and the decision made today doesn't necessarily hold a week from today because the situation's changed.
What about tolerance?
You mentioned how Patton just fired these people, demoted other people, sent them back.
Would you think that Batten was a great leader?
I think you've said that during these interviews.
I think he's an outstanding leader.
One of the superior leaders in the Army.
All he did was get the commendation of every man that hadn't gotten letters in six or eight weeks.
The proof of the pudding is that General Eisenhower and ultimately the Secretary of War in those days upheld it.
and never questioned it.
And those gentlemen have veto power over anything you do.
Me moving from A to B, if it hadn't been satisfactory all the way up the line, they could have jerked my ass and sent me home quick.
I'll tell you one experience I had with this.
What I mean by it, it was a dear experience to me.
We were in an
a little German town named Schmid.
Just after we went into Germany, there was a bombed out church, typical Catholic church, where the apse or the sanctuary is long and then the rectory up here and the pope and all up here.
And the whole back end, meaning the
apps of the pulpit, the cross and all were blown out, bombed out, artillery got here or something, I don't know.
Anyway, the pews were in the back of the church were dusty and full of snow, but still usable.
And the army had a system where they had one chaplain that would have four or five battalions to work in an area.
They may have had
10 battalions in this area, and they had a Protestant, a Catholic, and maybe a Jew rabbi.
And they worked around in these areas.
And they would come by or send their helper down and say, well, the chaplain wants to come by Sunday morning at 7 o'clock, have church.
And how about getting us a place to have church?
OK.

and you found a place to have church and you set the thing up and you put the word out to the area units next to you on either side and we could have church at such and such a crossroads and you come bring your boys down.
Any of them want to go to church, they can.
Well, our group had a Catholic chaplain who was head of the Jesuit school up here in Denver.
Joe something, I forget his name.
He was an educator.
And he's a good fella.
He loved, he played poker with us and he drank a little nip with us now and then, you know, in the evening.
And I'm sure he was a devout Catholic.
Anyway, this Baptist preacher sent word to me that he could hold service in our area at 7 o'clock, and me find him a place.
Well, I looked around, and the little old town's caput, except the back end of this church.
And the pews were still there, intact.
And I told my communications sergeant to, once they get the wire in, all they got to do is keep it in, and that's a relatively minor chore.
So they got time on their hands.
I said, sergeant, take care.
spare people down to the church and sweep all the snow off and get the debris off of eight or ten of those pews back here in the back end so we can have church down there Sunday.
And this was maybe Wednesday or Thursday, I don't know.
And he said, all right, and he did.
Well, this Catholic chapter helped me either supper, I mean, supper Thursday night or breakfast Friday morning.
What you could do down there at the church,
I'm going to have church service.
But you can't do that.
I said, oh, what are you talking about, Chaplain?
That's a church house, and Chaplain Jones is coming down here Sunday morning at 7 o'clock to have church.
So he told me to have a place, and that's where we're going to have it.
You can't do that.
I said, oh, get off and back now.
What's the problem?
He said, well, that's sanctified property.
And I'm not a Catholic.
I am a Christian, and I don't draw the line between them.
We all try and get the same heaven.
And I said, oh, hell, you just sit on over there on that peach tree and watch me.
I'm busy.
I got busy with something to get away from him.
But the point is, he went to the army chaplain, who was another Catholic, and the army chaplain

sent word i couldn't do that and i sent word back to him right down come down and breakfast at six o'clock and we go to church seven o'clock come come worship with us you know i was kind but i was completely telling him go to hell and he went back of course he blew up like a toad frog poison toad frog he went back and wrote an order
by command of General Simpson, the Army commander, that I would not do it.
Now, somehow, I got the premonition that SOB would do this.
And I hadn't gotten it by the time I went to bed Saturday night.
And I told my message center that I did not want to be disturbed.
And any messages came to me before 7 o'clock in the morning to hold them.

a message center is where any incoming messages go in and are tallied in by time and signature just like a registered mail is in our post office and so sure enough it came in after after i went to bed i don't know what time 11 12 o'clock at night came in my message center chief just sat on it and he gave it to me after church sunday morning and touted it to me at church yeah i mean he wrote it all out so
It would have stood up.
And of course, it had already been done.
And my chaplain wouldn't, that chaplain in our group wouldn't speak to me for a month after that.
But what I'm getting down to is can they do it?
About a week later, General Simpson, who was 9th Army Commander, came down in my area.
And I had my people keyed.
defensively for me, when any general officer came in the area, they'd get hold of me.

So I could go down there and report to him, introduce yourself to him if you didn't know him, ask him if you could be of any help to him in service, invite him to have a cup of coffee or something, you know.
Greet him in the area, see what he's looking for, and of course, defensively, I was interested in what the hell he was doing down there.
So I could protect
myself or the battalion.
And he came in the area and he saw a mess line.
He timed his time to arrive here so he could get in this mess line.
That's where those people would go to find information at.
So he stood in the enlisted mess line?
So he got in the enlisted mess line.
He borrowed a canteen and a mess kit from a soldier and went through and got his meal and went up and sat down on the rock and talked with the soldiers.
And of course, when I saw what was happening, I reported to him while they were still in this line.
He said, now, kiddo, I appreciate you coming down.
And you're a busy man, I know.
So you go on about your business.
I just want to get a meal here.
And I said, come on up to the office and message them.
No, I'd rather have a meal down here.
And I knew what Teddy was doing, but I didn't know why.
So I just faded out of the picture.
But I put my trusted
communications sergeant right behind him so he could gather all this information for me.
So I would know what was going on.

He asked them questions about their mail, about their food, about how I was taking care of them as far as medicine was concerned, were their PX rations adequate, and all the things that soldiers have close to their heart.

and of course I got a positive answer, affirmative answer on every one of them and when he left he sent his aide for me and thank him very much for his courtesy, extended and for the fine meal that he had.
He was glad to see that my soldiers were eating so well.
He liked the looks of my battalion and
Keep up the good work and left.
Well, this is a four-star general.

My communications sergeant told me after it all over what questions he asked and all, like about your mail and your PX supplies and where you're comfortably housed and how the rain and all that kind of thing.
And I dare say it was all a reflection of this chaplain business and having Christian church in the back end of this Catholic church and offended the Catholic chaplain.
And they reported me to him.
And General Simpson came down to find out, just like General Patton did.
Sure.
And I got affirmative reports on every category, so all he could do was say, you got a good battalion, keep up the good work, boy.

But if one of those soldiers had cracked a damn foot of slop, or, no, I haven't gotten any mail, or we're not getting none of the cigarettes or something like that, well, old Kidwell would have been gone home as a captain and still be a captain.
But I got the other report.
And so I...
So leadership, then, has a heck of a lot to do with satisfying the needs of your men.
Absolutely.
Everything.
Because if the men aren't happy, they won't do their job.
Right.
If you keep a man satisfied and he can see himself accomplishing something, he'll do it.
And that's leadership.
That's leadership to me.
Okay, let's say that, General, they called you and asked you to come to A&M and said...
Talk to these young 19-year-old corpsmen here and tell them how to become a leader.
How would you respond to that?
You've got to know your job.
And you have to have the capabilities of portraying that knowledge to your men.
And whether leadership is a God-given right or whether it's developed
or whether it's accidental.
Educators and psychologists will have to determine that.
I don't know.
Probably a blend of all of it.
I think some people are more born leaders than others.
Then again, if a man has the desire, he can equip himself to do the job.
And by demonstration, he can excel the others.
And that's where the cream rises to the top.
If a man wants to do his job, he can do it.
But he's got to know his job first.
And he's got to be able to portray that knowledge to his other people.
